patterns.example_ko: 시장에 가서 사느니, 비싸더라도 백화점에서 살래요.
patterns.example_en: Rather than buying it at the market, I’d buy it at the department store even if it’s pricey.
patterns.description: Choose the lesser of two undesirable options: 'rather than A, (do) B.'
patterns.tip: Often used with 차라리 for emphasis; good for soft but clear preferences.

patterns.example_ko: 늦게 출발할 바에야 그냥 내일 출발합시다.
patterns.example_en: If we’re going to leave late, let’s just leave tomorrow.
patterns.description: Stronger concession than -느니; if A is that bad, B is distinctly better.
patterns.tip: Use when option A feels unacceptable enough to justify switching plans.

patterns.example_ko: 열심히 준비했건만 결과가 기대에 못 미쳤다.
patterns.example_en: I prepared hard, yet the result fell short of expectations.
patterns.description: Contrasts effort/expectation with an opposite outcome.
patterns.tip: Adds a regretful tone; good for reflective or formal narratives.

patterns.example_en: It’s more accurate to say I was disappointed than angry.
patterns.description: Refines/corrects a label: 'not so much A as B.'
patterns.tip: Useful for nuanced feedback or polite disagreement.

patterns.example_ko: 그가 온다니까 기다렸는데 결국 안 왔어요.
patterns.example_en: He said he’d come, so I waited, but he didn’t show up.
patterns.description: Report what someone said; often implies expectation based on it.
patterns.tip: Can carry a faint 'and yet…' nuance if the outcome differed.

patterns.example_en: I heard you’re moving tomorrow?
patterns.tip: Softens a question and checks facts without sounding blunt.

patterns.example_ko: 기상청에 의하면 내일 눈이 올 거래요.
patterns.example_en: According to the weather agency, it will snow tomorrow.
patterns.tip: Use in reports, presentations, or academic-style writing.

patterns.example_en: We inform you that you have been accepted.
patterns.description: Formal nominalization often seen in notices and writing.
patterns.tip: Great for headings, notices, and succinct formal statements.

patterns.example_ko: 이 문제를 해결하는 데 시간이 많이 걸렸어요.
patterns.example_en: It took a lot of time to solve this problem.
patterns.description: Nominalizes a clause to indicate purpose/extent/context.
patterns.tip: Commonly used with 들다/걸리다/필요하다 to express resources.

patterns.example_ko: 알려 드리는 바와 같이 일정이 변경되었습니다.
patterns.example_en: As we inform you, the schedule has changed.
patterns.tip: Fits official announcements, press releases, and formal emails.

patterns.example_en: Due to the accident, traffic was paralyzed.
patterns.tip: Preferred in news, reports, and formal explanations.

patterns.example_ko: 아이들이 떠드는 통에 집중을 못 했어요.
patterns.example_en: Because the kids were noisy, I couldn’t concentrate.
patterns.description: Chaotic/troublesome cause leading to a negative result.
patterns.tip: Conveys inconvenience or disruption; colloquial/formal-neutral.

patterns.example_en: Because of the typhoon, there was significant damage.
patterns.tip: Use sparingly in serious/formal contexts (reports, news).

patterns.example_en: Since you agreed to help, you should fulfill your responsibility.
patterns.description: Given that A is true, B is expected/justified.
patterns.tip: Bridges past commitment to present expectation.

patterns.example_en: Now that you’ve promised, you must keep it.
patterns.tip: Great for rules, policies, and principled stances.

patterns.example_ko: 바쁘기로서니 연락 한 번은 할 수 있잖아요.
patterns.example_en: Busy as you may be, you could at least call once.
patterns.description: Concedes A but pushes back: 'even if A, still B.'
patterns.tip: Adds a slightly reproachful tone—use carefully.

patterns.example_ko: 빨리 발견했기에 망정이지 큰일 날 뻔했어요.
patterns.example_en: It’s a good thing we found it early; otherwise it could’ve been serious.
patterns.tip: Pairs well with 뻔했다 to highlight near-miss scenarios.

patterns.example_en: They said they were helping, but they just got in the way.
patterns.description: Ironically frames someone’s stated intent vs. poor result.
patterns.tip: Carries a critical/ironic tone—avoid in delicate contexts.

patterns.example_en: By cooperating, they created synergy.
patterns.description: Means/measure that achieves a result: 'by V-ing.'
patterns.tip: Formal, good for reports and process descriptions.

patterns.example_en: I felt sorry calling at a late hour.
patterns.tip: Sits between spoken/written styles; keep sentences compact.

patterns.example_en: It looked like rain, so I brought an umbrella.
patterns.tip: Conversational; explains reactive decisions.

patterns.example_en: Even if it rains, we’ll depart.
patterns.tip: Pairs well with firm commitments or resolutions.

patterns.example_en: Even if it’s hard, don’t give up.
patterns.tip: Prefer in writing or speeches/announcements.

patterns.example_en: Even with lots of money, would one be happy?
patterns.tip: Often appears in questions with skeptical tone.

patterns.example_en: I’d rather die than break my promise.
patterns.tip: Dramatic—use sparingly and for weighty contexts.

patterns.example_en: Assuming he comes, we need to prepare.
patterns.tip: Useful for planning and scenario analysis.

patterns.example_en: I’ll pretend I didn’t hear it and let it go.
patterns.description: Treats something as if it (had) happened/not happened.
patterns.tip: Great for smoothing social interactions.

patterns.example_en: The moment class ended, students headed out.
patterns.tip: Narrative flourish; emphasizes speed/abruptness.

patterns.example_en: As soon as he arrived, he called.
patterns.description: Short for -자마자; tightly links two actions.
patterns.tip: Good for concise storytelling.

patterns.example_en: As long as it’s possible, I’ll do my best.
patterns.tip: Pairs naturally with 한/동안 expressions.

patterns.example_en: When I try to speak, I feel like crying.
patterns.description: When attempting to do A, B (often obstacle/emotion) follows.
patterns.tip: Adds intimacy to recounting difficult moments.

patterns.example_en: If you keep reading, your understanding deepens.
patterns.description: Literary: if one keeps doing A, B results.
patterns.tip: Perfect for essays with a reflective tone.

patterns.example_en: The result depends on how you prepare.
patterns.tip: Great for advice and coaching language.

patterns.example_en: Success depends on your mindset.
patterns.tip: Concise and proverbial—memorable in lessons.

patterns.example_en: Contact me as soon as you arrive.
patterns.description: ‘As soon as’ / ‘just as’ depending on context.
patterns.tip: For 'immediately when', use with action verbs in present/future.

patterns.example_ko: 은행 가는 김에 우편도 보내 주세요.
patterns.example_en: Since you’re going to the bank, please mail this too.
patterns.description: ‘While at it’; piggyback a task on another.
patterns.tip: Natural in daily planning; don’t overuse in formal writing.

patterns.example_en: I knew, yet I couldn’t say anything.
patterns.tip: Feels literary; use for dramatic contrast.

patterns.example_en: Even after apologizing, I wasn’t forgiven.
patterns.tip: Good for surprising or disappointing outcomes.

patterns.example_en: Despite the high cost, we signed the contract.
patterns.tip: Suited for reports, essays, and business contexts.

patterns.example_en: It felt familiar, as if I’d seen it in a dream.
patterns.tip: Nice for expressive descriptions and narratives.

patterns.example_en: I worked almost day and night.
patterns.tip: Conveys strong effort or near-total extent.

patterns.example_en: It’s expensive, and the quality isn’t great either.
patterns.tip: Use to strengthen a critical evaluation.

patterns.example_en: Far from helping, they only got in the way.
patterns.tip: Emphatic; avoid overuse to keep tone balanced.

patterns.example_en: He’s not only diligent but also highly capable.
patterns.tip: More neutral than -기는커녕; good in endorsements.

patterns.example_en: I’ll allow it, but with conditions.
patterns.tip: Feels legalistic/official—fits rules and clauses.

patterns.example_en: Even my family didn’t believe me.
patterns.tip: Heightens drama; use to mark final straw or surprise.

patterns.example_ko: 서울을 비롯해서 전국 곳곳에 분점이 있다.
patterns.example_en: There are branches nationwide, starting with Seoul.
patterns.tip: Great for spotlighting a key example among many.

patterns.example_en: These days, he keeps grumbling.
patterns.tip: Carries a negative nuance—use when that tone fits.

patterns.example_en: He’s habitually late to appointments.
patterns.tip: Pairs well with habitual adverbs (자주/늘/항상).

patterns.example_ko: 밥은 먹는 둥 마는 둥 했어.
patterns.example_en: I barely ate at all.
patterns.tip: Colloquial; conveys dissatisfaction with the effort.

patterns.example_en: My stomach was about to burst (that full).
patterns.tip: Vivid exaggeration—use for color in narratives.

patterns.example_en: I waited and waited, then finally left.
patterns.description: So much that it crosses a threshold.
patterns.tip: Implies buildup → breaking point.

patterns.example_en: I intended to help, but it ended up getting in the way.
patterns.tip: Explains mishaps without sounding defensive.

patterns.example_en: He keeps trying to interfere, and it’s uncomfortable.
patterns.tip: Useful for boundaries and complaints.

patterns.example_en: I was about to go out, but it rained so I gave up.
patterns.description: About to do A, but B happened and stopped it.
patterns.tip: Great for 'almost did' narratives.

patterns.example_en: He smiled as if nothing had happened.
patterns.description: ‘As if’; describes manner resembling a state.
patterns.tip: Nice for body-language descriptions.

patterns.example_en: He nodded as if to say it’s okay.
patterns.description: Non-verbal sign implying a quoted message.
patterns.tip: Pairs with gestures (끄덕이다, 미소 짓다).

patterns.example_en: He seems tired.
patterns.tip: Softer than 단정; polite inferences.

patterns.example_en: It’s bound to be heavy traffic.
patterns.tip: Use for 'called it' moments—don’t overdo negativity.

patterns.example_en: That sounds plausible.
patterns.tip: Neutral probability—good for balanced takes.

patterns.example_en: There’s no way that’s true.
patterns.tip: Stronger than 안/못; keep tone in mind.

patterns.example_en: If you overdo it, you’re likely to get hurt.
patterns.description: Tends to / is prone to happen.
patterns.tip: Useful for warnings and common-sense advice.

patterns.example_en: People are bound to make mistakes.
patterns.tip: Gentle reassurance in feedback/coaching.

patterns.example_en: When you put in effort, you naturally feel rewarded.
patterns.tip: Sounds proverbial—great for conclusions.

patterns.example_en: Some say it’s hard, while others say it’s fun.
patterns.tip: Balances two sides of an argument.

patterns.example_en: You keep going on about whether to go or not.
patterns.tip: Often carries a slightly exasperated tone.

patterns.example_en: I was busy all day cleaning and cooking.
patterns.description: Busy with A and B (hectic listing).
patterns.tip: Evokes bustle—nice in story openings.

patterns.example_en: Bring everything—books, notebooks, and all.
patterns.tip: Good for casual lists; keep items concrete.

patterns.example_en: After long discussions, they reached an agreement.
patterns.tip: Pairs well with nouns like 노력/논의/고민.

patterns.example_en: I finally pulled it off.
patterns.tip: Adds triumph; great for motivational contexts.

patterns.example_en: I was so tired that I couldn’t even respond.
patterns.tip: Use with emotions/conditions (기쁜/슬픈/화난).

patterns.example_en: It turned out harder than I thought.
patterns.tip: Conversational—keeps tone friendly and light.

patterns.example_en: I presented while many people were watching.
patterns.tip: Useful for formal event descriptions.

patterns.example_ko: 다 끝난 마당에 이제 와서 왜 그래?
patterns.example_en: Now that it’s all over, why bring it up?
patterns.description: Highlights a (late) stage that makes the point stronger.
patterns.tip: Often rhetorical and slightly scolding.

patterns.example_en: For a beginner, your pronunciation is quite good.
patterns.tip: Nice for compliments with context.

patterns.example_en: Preferences change according to age.
patterns.tip: Common in surveys, reports, and analyses.

patterns.example_en: It was extremely (by no means easy).
patterns.description: Idiomatic double negative for strong emphasis.
patterns.tip: Sounds formal/stylistic; great for emphasis in writing.

patterns.example_en: I was extremely satisfied.
patterns.tip: Perfect for polished reviews and speeches.

patterns.example_en: Even if I wanted to believe it, I can’t.
patterns.tip: Good for expressing constraints beyond one’s control.

patterns.example_en: Do so (old/formal tone).
patterns.tip: Use in historical/literary contexts; avoid in daily speech.

patterns.example_en: Do it that way (semi-formal directive).
patterns.description: Older/formal style, senior-to-junior or in literature.
patterns.tip: Shows hierarchy; sounds old-fashioned in modern settings.

patterns.example_en: Since there’s no time, let’s do it next time.
patterns.tip: Solid for reports and official notices.

patterns.example_en: It helps, but there are limits.
patterns.tip: Smoother than 하지만 in formal writing.

patterns.example_en: The price is low, and the quality is good.
patterns.tip: Great for specs, brochures, and resumes.

patterns.example_en: The door was closed / (I) made someone close the door.
patterns.description: Passive vs. causative voice formation and usage.
patterns.tip: Teach side-by-side to contrast subject roles clearly.

patterns.example_en: I hurried for fear of being late.
patterns.tip: Elevated tone; pairs with 걱정/염려 contexts.

patterns.example_en: He acted as if he didn’t know.
patterns.description: Pretending/acting as though a state is true.
patterns.tip: Conveys subtle sarcasm or indirect criticism.

patterns.example_en: While conducting research, we also carried out teaching.
patterns.tip: Use in project write-ups and CVs.

patterns.example_en: There’s no way that could happen.
patterns.tip: Emphatic; keep for decisive rebuttals.

sources.note: Official/product listing confirming the 22-chapter structure and themes
